title: Communication Access Real-Time Translation Through Collaborative Correction of Automatic Speech Recognition
author: Korbinian Kuhn (Stuttgart Media University), Verena Kersken (Stuttgart Media University), Gottfried Zimmermann (Stuttgart Media University), ...
relevance_why: This paper focuses on enhancing Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) through collaborative correction, which could influence Haohe Liu's research in audio and speech processing by integrating innovative human-in-the-loop strategies.
background: The study investigates real-time captioning for Deaf and hard of hearing individuals, addressing challenges in transcription accuracy and accessibility.
contribution: This paper introduces a workflow for real-time correction of Automatic Speech Recognition outputs by non-professionals, achieving improved transcription clarity for DHH users.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Standard ASR systems often yield lower transcription accuracy, especially under varying conditions and speaker diversity.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages collaborative editing to enhance accuracy and readability of ASR outputs, reducing errors substantially compared to traditional ASR systems.

key_innovation: The method engages non-professionals in correcting ASR outputs collaboratively, potentially creating a more accessible and cost-effective captioning solution.
real_world_impact: Enhancing caption accuracy for DHH individuals can significantly improve their accessibility to spoken content in various environments, potentially transforming public event participation.
limitations: The study's findings may not generalize to all contexts due to testing on a single high-quality video recording.

new_terms.collaborative editing: **Collaborative editing** refers to multiple users jointly refining or correcting a text in real-time, leveraging their collective input to enhance quality.
